comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: George McAneny (1869-1953), New York Times executive manager, president of the Borough of Manhattan, among his other jobs: diglib.princeton.edu/ead/getEad?eadid=MC091&kw=

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
McAneny was speaking in the presence of a journalism rival, Ralph Pulitzer, publisher of the New York World. Pulitzer, seated at right, in a ceremony at Columbia University's School of Journalism, held during Commencement Week (June 2, 1914), presented the University with a bronze statue of Thomas Jefferson. In this photo, the statue is shrouded in bunting prior to the great unveiling.

Other Bain/LOC photos of the unveiling ceremony:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5497263168/in/photostream/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5496669463/in/photostream/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5496668869/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: pennylrichardsca, swanq & Wystan: Thanks for the further information on the speaker, the statue and the event, as well as for the gathering of related photographs. The statue, a gift of the Joseph Pulitzer estate, was actually unveiled in a ceremony on June 2, rather than on Commencement Day, per this New York Times article. We will add these details to this record and to the other related photographs when we update.
